content.description:
Start by a pitch of pure ice when in good condition about 30 meters until your reach a tree with multiple sling.  

Then start the long snow or scree slope depending of the condition until the summit solo climbing or simul climb is strongly recommended here.

«Descent» : by the hiking trail or by ski when the condition are in!



The first couloir of the Mountain from the Town the easiest looking couloir of the mountain

Sling for tree and a short ice screw rack

The easiest of the routes on Mont Saint Pierre. Moderate gully climbing with some sections of ice and chossy alpine rock. There are many options, so follow your chosen path of least resistance. The first pitch is usually a full pitch of ice followed by a lot of moderate snow climbing and some cruxy mixed sections up higher. Conditions can vary greatly depending on the season. Identify the ice pitches that flow out the bottom of the gullies on the Northwest Face of Mont Saint Pierre. Ouskissont? is the second gully closest to town. Ice screws and pitons were especially useful. I also brought a rack of nuts.

The small village of Mont-Saint-Pierre is 55 km East of Sainte-Anne-des-Monts. There are numerous ice climbs near town, but the most notable routes ascent the 400-meter Northwest face of the namesake mountain on the East edge of town. These climbs rise right over the Saint Lawrence, thus the views are spectacular. The routes follow long gullies and can meander onto the rocky aretes to either side. Expect ice, snow and chossy rock. Ice can be thin at times and the rock can be quite suspect. As a result, the climbs can be rather runout. Pitons are very useful in the abundant chossy blocks. Be aware of avalanche danger. Check conditions in the Chic-Chocs on the Avalanche Quebec website.
